thread.title: Week seven: "Code Red" for Cousins and Washington vs. the Bucs
thread.title_full: Week seven: "Code Red" for Cousins and Washington vs. the Bucs

title: Week seven: "Code Red" for Cousins and Washington vs. the Bucs
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Week seven: "Code Red" for Cousins and Washington vs. the Bucs We preview the key match up ahead of the Redskins "code red" game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Post to Facebook Week seven: "Code Red" for Cousins and Washington vs. the Bucs We preview the key match up ahead of the Redskins "code red" game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.  //on.wusa9.com/1LSEwhh   Week seven: "Code Red" for Cousins and Washington vs. the Bucs Sam C. LaPaille, WUSA9 4:17 p.m. EDT October 23, 2015 Oct 4, 2015; Landover, MD, USA; Washington Redskins quarterback Kirk Cousins (8) is congratulated by Washington Redskins head coach Jay Gruden after scoring a touchdown against the Philadelphia Eagles during the first half at FedEx Field. Mandatory Credit: Brad Mills-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Brad Mills, Brad Mills-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET   
WASHINGTON (WUSA9) -- The Washington Redskins (2-4) are set to take on the Tampa Bay Buccaneers (2-3) on Sunday afternoon at FedEx Field. 
After a "tale of two halves" loss against the New York Jets on October 11 that saw the Redskins lead 13-10 at half, only to lose the game 34-20 after a dismal second half, head coach Jay Gruden has deemed Sunday's match up a "code red." Win and improve to 3-4 and the NFC East crown is still within reach. Lose and fall to 2-5 and big change could be on the horizon in Washington. 
We take a look at the key match up (yes, singular) going into Sunday's tilt with the Bucs: 
QB Kirk Cousins vs. QB Jameis Winston 
Throw out every other match up in this game because honestly, in the grand scheme of things, only one matters; the struggling Kirk Cousins versus 2015 number one overall pick Jameis Winston. 
First, let's recap Cousins' past two weeks. 
On October 4, Cousins completed 21-32 passes for 219 yards, one touchdown and two interceptions in a loss against the Atlanta Falcons. Cousins' first pick was "unlucky" as the ball bounced off a sliding Pierre Garcon's hands and went right into the hands of Atlanta's Robert Alford. 
Oct 11, 2015; Atlanta, GA, USA; Washington Redskins quarterback Kirk Cousins (8) passes against the Atlanta Falcons during the fourth quarter at the Georgia Dome. The Falcons defeated the Redskins 25-19 in overtime. Mandatory Credit: Dale Zanine-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Dale Zanine, Dale Zanine-USA TODAY Sports) 
But the next interception cost his team the game, literally. After leading a four play, 46-yard drive that resulted in the game-tying field goal as time expired, Cousins threw a pick-six on the seventh play of overtime. Falcons win 25-19. Game over. 
Fast forward to October 11 and a week six showdown against the Jets in New York. A banged-up Redskins squad battled to a 13-10 halftime lead. CB Bashaud Breeland forced three turnovers, and Cousins played a solid half which included zero turnovers and a two-yard touchdown strike to WR Pierre Garcon. 
But a different Kirk Cousins and Redskins offense emerged from the locker room at the start of the third quarter. On his first possession of the second half, Cousins threw an ugly pick to all-pro corner Darrelle Revis. The throw came late (very late), violating the league's unwritten rule on Revis: "You do NOT throw late towards Darrelle Revis." On the very next play, Jets QB Ryan Fitzpatrick scampered down the middle of the field for a 18-yard touchdown run and the Jets took a 20-13 lead and never looked back. 
Oct 18, 2015; East Rutherford, NJ, USA; Washington Redskins quarterback Kirk Cousins (8) prepares to throw the ball in the first quarter against the New York Jets at MetLife Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Vincent Carchietta-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Vincent Carchietta, Vincent Carchietta-USA TODAY Sports) 
Cousins threw another interception two possessions later which lead to the Jets' knockout blow, a two-yard touchdown pass to WR Eric Decker, giving the Jets an insurmountable 34-13 lead with less than a quarter to play. Cousins finished the day with numbers eerily similar to the Atlanta game; 23-45, 196 yards, one touchdown and two interceptions. 
So why is this the only match up that matters this week? Because this is a game for Kirk Cousins to silence the critics and take a step forward instead of taking another giant step back. There is a common theme in the Redskins' four losses this year: Multiple turnovers by Cousins. Captain Kirk has thrown two interceptions in each of his four losses this season. And in Washington's two wins in 2015, Cousins has thrown zero picks. 
Simply put: If Kirk takes care of the ball, the Redskins win. 
Jameis Winston has had a typical rookie season thus far, throwing for seven touchdowns but also throwing seven interceptions and losing three fumbles. He has the sixth-lowest QBR in the league at 38.4 and just like Cousins, all seven of his interceptions have come in the Bucs' three losses this season. 
This is a game where Cousins needs to outplay Winston. Cousins needs to validate why he was chosen over both Robert Griffin III and Colt McCoy for the starting quarterback job, and that he is more than capable of leading the offense. Getting outplayed by a struggling rookie could spell trouble on the horizon for Cousins. 
We've heard Gruden's confidence in Cousins the entire season: He can make all the throws, he is the quarterback for the system and so on. 
Now, it's time to go prove it and put an end to the discussion.
